SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Wes Cowell
2. Your address: 1000 28th Street, Regina, Saskatchewan
3. Date: March 28, 1962
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Liverpool, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): Fall 1906
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   - Liverpool, England
   - Regina, Saskatchewan
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," etc.) When I was 12.
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   - To find work and something better than living in England
   - I had an English education
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    - Through my brother who came first when the Brown Colonists came and we returned two years later. I went back with him.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They were in favor of it.

My Dad said my fate.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my brother who was returning after a visit.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Steamship, "Vancouver," "Empress."

Storage on an old car, river and then by rail to Calgary. We worked there so went back to Fortage in Prairie where my brother had worked in 1903.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Poveshell on Form 3, Section of Poveshell.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? end of March 1907, near Mr. Burtell.

This first land of South of Mullinor Josh, near Mr. Burtell.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Raised on Doll farm in England, then Cattle for Mr. Smithson in Montana or Saskatchewan.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They were in favor of it. My Dad said my folks.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my brother who was returning off a visit.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Steamer "Brampton." Traveling by rail to Calgary. We went there by train and back by horse.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Portage la Prairie where my brother had worked.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

For $23 a month, I stayed at Mrs. Smith's house.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? end of May 1907, took up land near Mrs. Smith's place.

17f. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Then I moved to Swift Current, then to Balgonie, then to Regina.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

I worked on a farm in England, then came to Canada in 1903.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

My family came and helped, and returned to England after about two years.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

PP. I may say they already been the pioneers of my family.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Well yes, many things happened. When I arrived at Willowbrook after a long trip, my car was stolen by a thief. I had no money and no place to stay overnight, but somehow I found shelter in an empty barn two miles from where I worked. For several days, I walked in these fields, released and free, until I could find work. I worked hard and saved enough to build a new house. For weeks of my work, I saved money and helped others. Today, there are many of the pioneers still working.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

As I didn't travel far in the early days, I only took a trip to the Rocky Mountains from Johnson, and have never made another trip.
